data.title: Tricky Math
data.statement:
Olivia wants to know, if she takes all numbers, whose <<all digits are same>> (e.g. 1,2,3,...8,9,11,22,33,44,...99,111,222,333... and so on) and do limits: [[L]] is the minimum number of digits, that these numbers can have and [[R]] is the maximum, how many <<digits>> she could get.

For example:
For L=1 and R=3 she could have only numbers (1,2,3...,8,9,11,22,33,...88,99,...111,222,...,888,999  (where number 1 has one digit and number 888 has three digits)) and the answer will be counting all digits of these numbers = 54.
data.stubGenerator:
read L:int
read R:int
write a number of all digits
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>> An integer [[L]], which is <<lower limit>> of a number of digits that numbers, whose all digits same, have.
<<Line 2>> An integer [[R]], which is <<upper limit>> of a number of digits that numbers, whose all digits same, have.
data.outputDescription: One integer, which is a number of digits, that numbers, whose all digits are same, have.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Olivia wants to know, if she takes all numbers, whose all digits are same (e.g. 1,2,3,...8,9,11,22,33,44,...99,111,222,333... and so on) and do limits: L is the minimum number of digits, that these numbers can have and R is the maximum, how many digits she could get.

For example:
For L=1 and R=3 she could have only numbers (1,2,3...,8,9,11,22,33,...88,99,...111,222,...,888,999 (where number 1 has one digit and number 888 has three digits)) and the answer will be counting all digits of these numbers = 54.
Input
Line 1 An integer L, which is lower limit of a number of digits that numbers, whose all digits same, have.
Line 2 An integer R, which is upper limit of a number of digits that numbers, whose all digits same, have.
Output
One integer, which is a number of digits, that numbers, whose all digits are same, have.
Constraints
1<=L<=9
1<=R<=9
Example
Input
1
3
Output
54
